Staff is speedy and efficient without being jerks.  

They have some good bottled soda selection too, if you're in the mood for something a little different to drink.  Vintage Coke machine inside for cool atmosphere points!
author: Johanna K.

description:
What I really wanted was the wood-fired Margherita pizza but I wound up with an oven-baked slice instead.  I was underwhelmed.  The sauce was just ok and the crust was very crispy-- probably due to the reheating.
Next time I'll sit in the restaurant next door and order the wood-fired version.  There are several different types of ovens used at Tony's for various pizzas.  It's best to do your homework first before ordering a slice here.
author: Thomas D.

description: Delicious, light , fresh and surprisingly mouth watering every time. Tonight was the 4 cheeses and it practically melted in our mouths.
author: Janet K.

description:
Had lunch at this place over the weekend. Ordered a slice of New York cheese and because the pie had just come out, it was fresh and tasted great. The pizza has the right amount of chew and thin crust, on the more cheesy side than I prefer. Sometimes if they have to reheat the slice for you then it becomes very chewy and may somewhat hurt your jaw because you have to chew so much :) 

Enjoyed it very much, highly recommend it
author: Hemant D.

description:
I really hate to do this but it needs to be done. Rarely, if ever would I give a place a one star review. First,it hurts to do this as a former business owner. I know how hard it is to run a business. And believe it or not, I really like Tony's and their sister restaurant Capo's. But my customer service experience was so bad yesterday that I'm not sure I will ever go to either again. I have been to both places several times and have even recommended them to others. But when a business becomes too successful and starts treating customers like cattle, then it's time to speak up. 

Yesterday I called the slice house and ordered a pizza ahead of time. I called, was put on hold for 10 minutes, then hung up on. I called back and spoke to a very rushed person. She told me it would be about 60 minutes for delivery and 30 minutes if I could pick it up. I opted to pick it up. I arrived to find a line of about 30 people waiting to order and complete chaos inside. I asked those in line if they had already ordered and was told that they had not. Several customers told me to go ahead and ask to pay for the pizza I had already ordered. When I asked the person at the counter he said..."no....go to the back of the line". I asked, "Really? That is why I called ahead. Do I really have to get in line and wait an hour, while the pizza you made sits there?" He said "yes" and walked away. 

I then went over to Tony's and asked to speak with a manager. The same guy came out but this time he was more empathetic. "I know what you're saying. It's not a good policy but it's what we're told to do." I asked, "So then what's the advantage of calling ahead? You get cold food when you call ahead? That makes no sense."

He said "I know. Sorry." Then...he STILL would not give me the pizza that was siting there???? Unreal. Never again. I know you probably don't care Tonys but I have been to your restaurant at least 30 times and its obvious that you do not care if I come back. And I won't. And I will never recommend you to others again. 

The story has a happy ending. Tomassos on Kearny made me an awesome pizza and they treated me as if they appreciated the business. They even said "Thank you!" And they have a new customer. :)
author: Edward N.

description:
Just ate at Tony's slice house
Tried to get a table at Tony's but the host was a serious B
Went next door and was greeted by a super cute super friendly girl with a Bernie and tattoos very helpful and will defiantly come back.                                                                              The restaurant ?   Will have to wait
author: Ed M.

description:
We came to Tony's on a saturday afternoon, stupidly hoping we might be able to get a seat without too long of a wait. Clearly, the hour+ wait meant that was not going to happen. So instead we went next door to Tony's slice to go shop. The line was much faster there, and it only took us about 10 minutes to get to the counter.

We ordered a few slices of the meat lover's pizza. To be honest, I was not very impressed. It seemed average at best. I know Tony's has all types of specialty pizza styles when you get seated inside, but the slice house only serves a basic new york style with little in the way of options.

On the positive side, it is almost entirely outdoor seating, and the park is just across the street, so this is a very dog friendly option.
author: Mark O.

description:
Large slices, perfect for splitting with a friend. Great crust and toppings. Purple potato, pepperoni, and cheese. One of the best cheese slices ever.

I had to reheat. If you dont know this trick, put pizza in cast iron or comparable pan and hear from the bottom until cheese is melted. This technique makes sure it's crispy again and this crust takes to this preparation very well.

I'll be back!! Friendly staff too
author: John V.

description:
Recommended by a local tour guide (because they won a pizza prize in Italy). The place was busy but not as bad as the sit-down Tony's Pizza next door -- we had joined the long line there first, but the hostess assured us the takeout place served the same pizzas.

We tried a slice of thin crust pizza with cheese & pepperoni, and slice of square, thick crust pizza with sausage and red & yellow pepper strips. We did not find either slice particularly outstanding. They were also very salty. And at $13 for the two slices, they were clearly priced for tourists.
author: Trong D.

description: Great slice of 4-cheese pizza. If you're in a hurry and want a cheap, delicious slice-come here.
author: Hannah S.

description:
Avoid the 2 hour wait (at 10 pm on a Sunday) at Tony's next door, and order your food at the Slice House.  You can order just about anything from Tony's regular menu, minus a few of the appetizers.  This includes the AMAZING meatballs ($5 for 3) from Tony's menu.  

I have tried a few of their pizzas, but the best is the Cal Italia.  It is the perfect combination of salty, sweet and rich.  Get that and some meatballs to go. Trust me.

I have also tried a few of their slices, a basic cheese and meaty Sicilian.  Both of those are amazing as well.  The Sicilian isn't as heavy as it looks, the crust is nice and airy with a crisp oily edge.

I walked by here on a Tuesday once and noticed that it was open - a day that the regular Tony's is closed.  I'm not sure if you can get the full menu then, but you can definitely get a slice.
author: Mark A.

description:
I am definitely a huge fan of Tony's pizza, but the restaurant itself is completely different than the slice house. The slice house is a place where you go and just get pizza either to-go or to eat there and get back to your day. The pizzas are previously made and are just heated up, but still taste great. 

I had the New Yorker and the Margherita in the restaurant, and went back the next day to the slice house and tried the Margherita again, and it wasn't the same. It was still good, but nothing beats the original restaurant. 

This is a definite alternative to the restaurant, but if you can, please take my word and go to the restaurant and enjoy the best pizza!
author: Melvin M.

description:
Their Sicilian styled pizza!  The crust is so fresh, soft and SO FLUFFY!

Simple pizza restaurant where you can just order up at the register and they call out your order when it's ready.  The space inside has just one big booth for dining and there are a couple of seats and tables outside.

This place is located in a nice, chill area and a great place to lounge outside if you have the time to do so!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Tony's is where I go when I want a thin and delicious slice that reminds me of home on the East Coast. I'm picky when it comes to pizza here, and this is by far the best I've had. 

Their slices are HUGE and decently priced for the amount of pizza you get.

The calzones are a wonder in of themselves, and the staff is always super friendly. I constantly recommend Tony's to friends and customers since I work nearby!
author: Jessica L.

description: First they didn't give me the second slice that I ordered. After 10 min the second slice came up but it wasn't the one that I ordered. When I told them this isn't the one they got mad at me, one of the staff was murmuring some bad words... Then he gave me the right slice without warm it up. WTF! What kind of service is that? Do something wrong, don't even apologized and give me a cold slice. I had an amazing experience at the corner restaurant many times but this slice place has horrible service, rude and unprofessional staff members...
author: Sinan D.

description:
One hour wait at Tony's? Ain't nobody got time for that!!

Tony's Slice House, two doors down from Tony's flagship restaurant is a blessing for those who desire a quick slice without the wait, and it's open till 11pm! Past that hour, you'll have to go to different style of Sicilian pizza at nearby Golden Boy. 

Note: NY Pizza style mostly served at the slice house & it's a bit different from the actual Tony's where Neopolitan style is king. Sicilian slices available too, and strangely, Italian Beef sandwiches from Chicago.

So how do you tell a NY slice of pizza is good? According to SeriousEats.com...

- Thin layer of crispness at the very bottom: Check.
- Soft, chewy, moist crumb: Check.
- Pepperoni slices that curled up: Check
- Bright & Savory sauce, not sweet: Check
- Cheese fully melted, starting to brown but not causing a thick blanket: Check

All the makings of a great pizza!

NY Cheese Slice: $4.50
NY Pepperoni Slice: $4.50
Way oversized pizza box for takeout: $.25, lolwat?
Yummy level: :P
author: Steven C.

description: Do not go here if you want Italian beef sandwiches because they are inconsistent and really only do pizza well.  They offer sausage with it on the menu but I have asked 3 separate times and they always say they are out.  Also, they never answer their phone for carry out.
author: Michael H.

description:
This is a dump.  Bit of a bait and switch with the rude, slow service from slice house next door when you call Tony's. Airport quality pizza a hour later, with a rude guy at the counter.  Kept me waiting for 30m after etc and didn't actually start making my pizza until 45m after I made the order. 

Total waste of time and money.  $64 for two pizzas. One Margherita and one New Yorker.  I've had much much better.  

Stay away.
author: Praneeth W.

description: Went Sunday paid $17.50 for 3 slices pizza was dry no sauce they did not warm up the pizza in oven  I thought this was a 5 star place  famous tony  name tarnished
author: Bipin P.

description:
There are days that I show up to eat at Tony's only to find the line too long for a table or I am so hungry that I can not wait.  This brings me next door to the Slice House.  The pizza is as good or better than anything that you get in NYC.  The slice is huge.  The toppings are generous.  The price matches the size of the slice, about $4.25/slice.  2 slices is enough to be full, but there is a strong desire for a 3rd.  

What did I learn today?  Heaven is filled with Tony's pizza, Mexican Coke in a bottle, and bicycles with endless newly paved roads.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Came to the city last weekend with the fam to celebrate my birthday!

For dinner, we were looking for something fast and good ;) Came to Tony's on recommendation from our wine tour guide. We had originally wanted to go to the restaurant, but the wait was 1 hour 45 minutes so we ended up at the slice house.

We got an assortment of slices (NY cheese, California veggie, purple potato, and NY meat lover). We also got some cokes from their cool old timey machine. The za was very good. Nice and thin. Good crisp. Nice tomato sauce. 

The purple potato gets a lot of love on yelp, but I didn't think it was anything special. It was greasier than the other slices and didn't have tomato sauce (which I think is essential to judging a pizza place). 

They had plentiful seating outside, which was nice, but cold since it's usually freezing in the city regardless of the time of year. However, it was a nice alternative to waiting for an hour and 45 minutes.

The only bummer was that they don't serve the delicious looking meatballs at the slice house. I suppose we'll have to return to the restaurant for the meatballs. 

Also, as everywhere in the city, parking sucks buttocks.
author: Angela D.

description: I'm a north beach guy, and I'm from brooklyn, so i know my pizza. Avoid this place, despite what you might have heard. The quality control is terrible, pizzas sit for a long time, and are often stale by the time they're reheated. The slice house staff is also UNUSUALLY UNFRIENDLY, and almost aggressively condescending. Go around the corner too Golden Boy for a great slice of pizza in a far friendlier pizzeria.
author: stephen h.

description: Best pizza I've had in San Francisco.  I had the Potato, Bacon, and something.... It was close to perfect, the crust!, no one can figure out how to make a really good crust, these guys did. The only tough part to swallow is the price, $5.97 for a medium sized slice of pizza!!   I'll be back- just not as often as I'd like.
author: M M.

description: Fast and yummy. Get the NY cheese slice. Extra stars for the guy at the counter that gave me a bandaids from the first aid kit for my worn out tourist feet!
author: AJ M.

description:
I had heard about Tony's for years, but I had never made a point to go to the restaurant for a pizza.  I had also heard they had a slice shop, but I had never randomly been in the neighborhood... until now!  When I saw that we were taking a 15 minute break during a team event right across the street from the slice shop, I knew that I had to order a slice.

As I've mentioned before, I am a cheese pizza lover, so my choice was easy - a slice of the New York cheese.  It was large, it was greasy, and it was perfect!  I sprinkled some crushed red peppers on that bad boy, folded it in half, and went to town.  I didn't care that I had grease running down my hand.  I didn't care that I was eating lunch an hour later. It was perfection - piping hot, crispy crust, good sauce, and tasty cheese.

Next time, I'll come back with the wife, and we'll try a few different things - the New York, the margherita, and perhaps the Italian Beef. Now that I've had the slice shop, I'm not sure I even need to try the sit down restaurant next door!
author: Nadeem A.

description:
Hey Yelp!  If Zagat, Urbanspoon, Google Plus, MenuPages, SFGate, SeriousEats etc all list out "Tony's Coal-Fired Pizza & Slice House" as a separate business from Tony's Pizza Napoletana, shouldn't this place deserve its own Yelp listing?

http://www.zagat.com/r/tonys-coal-fired-pizza-slice-house-san-francisco

In 2010, Tony Gemignani purchased the 1556 Stockton space and turned the shuttered La Spiaggia Delicatessen into Tony's Coal-Fired Pizza And Slice House.  Its own red-awning boasts of Chicago Italian Beef.   The website for Tony's Pizza Napolentana mentions Capo's but doesn't even mention its neighboring take-out haven.

Tony's Pizza Napoletana at the corner has a bar and is a sit-down and they won't do any take-out orders (I asked).

TCFP&SH is mostly fast-food / take-out-oriented, save a small black rounded 4-seater and a few small tables outside.

TPN is business-lunch friendly whereas TCFP&SH is by the slice and serves on paper plates.  If I recall correctly, the menu at TCFP&SH was a sheet of paper showing what's in the deli case, such as the Californian, NY Slice, Sicilian, Picante, Stromboli, Calzone, and Proscuitto Panini

I got the New York slice (cheese slice) - $3.75.  It replaced Arinell's for the cheese slice on the 2013 7x7 100 Big Eats.   The crust was very light and almost crispy.  Cheese slices are usually very greasy but this one is only just a little bit greasy.

The system is pretty standard.  You look at the display case, order and pay, they give you a receipt with a number on it, and they yell out your order when it's ready.  All the fixings are located  at the top of the counter.  To-go boxes are 50 cents each.

Beverages are located in a retro ice box to the left.  You pay with your order and grab the bottle you like.

When I ate my slice, locals and tourists were in and out non-stop.  Most people took their slices to-go and ate at the park across the street, but I am averse to sitting out in the sun on a hot day.

The ambiance is very different from the sit-down Tony's at the corner where there was a line of 6 business-looking people waiting to be acknowledged by the hostess.

The receipt shows the 1570 Stockton address and its parent company name but it's just for ease of administration.  In order for the ratings for the corner store to be accurate and fair, there really needs to be a separate listing for this single-serving slice house!
author: Winnie L.

description:
Extremely lame customer service for overrated pizza. Called in for a takeout order and was told it would be ready by 5. However, the pizza was not ready and the guy at the counter told me to "just chill" after waiting for another 20 minutes after the appointed time. Finally got the pizza after waiting for 30 minutes, which defeats the purpose of calling in a phone order. Pizza was lukewarm... Apparently it was ready but no one at the counter bothered to check on the order. 

There are a couple of other great pizza places in town (Delfina). I won't revisit Tony's again for soggy and cold pizza.
author: Jessica K.

description:
I feel really bad giving bad reviews but we didn't want to wait an hour and a half for the restaurant so we thought the take out part of the restaurant would be a good option. We ordered our food about 450 and at 5:15 they said our pizza would be eight more minutes at 5:30 he said it would be three more minutes. At this point we talked to the manager. He checked to see what was happening and then said our pizza would be out soon. Then the church clock struck 6 and we had to get the manager again to which he started to get us a refund. The guy who was cooking the pizza was argumentative in front of his boss and to us saying he didn't care even though the boss was saying it was their bad not ours we are correct to not to have to wait over an hour for pizza that they said would take 20 mins. We could've just ordered slices and already be done and gone. 

Either he wants to get fired or he is family and can't get fired in which case I feel bad for the manager. 

So the pizza was good but this whole situation probably will have us not go back. 

Hope you don't have the luck we did.
author: Esther M.

description:
I saw Tony's on a recent "Best Pizza in America" list and decided to give it a try.

Here you can get NEW YORK style pizza and CHICAGO style Italian beef sandwiches. But you know what? This is California. Let's own up to ourselves-- we do some pretty great things, so let's stop trying to imitate other cities' trademark-style foods.

Tony's serves up a pretty okay $5+ slice of pie. Golden Boy is just around the corner and is better. Arizmendi really sets the example for the Bay Area though-- they serve up the best pizza I've had in a quintessentially California style. Quality, seasonal, locally-sourced ingredients (which happen to be vegetarian). Thin crust. F*cking California as sh*t.

Spoiler alert: you're not going to find New York style pizza in The Bay... but The Bay will give you its own equally awesome pizza if you go to the right place.

Color me well-fed-yet-unimpressed with Tony's.
author: K M.

description: I would recommend coming here!  Amazing pizza and great atmosphere.  My son had a kids pepperoni pizza and my husband and I ordered the New Yorker- interesting and delicious combination of flavors!
author: Tabitha W.

description: The pizza is beyond greasy, and not a big enough slice to charge $6 for. The slices are the size of a medium pizza slice at Little Ceaser's. It tasted mediocre at best. The cashier is/was rude, didn't even greet me. Never coming back again.
author: Chyanne R.

description:
The Italian tomato beef at Tony's slice house might have overtaken Portillo's as my favorite Italian beef sandwich of all time (although I will ALWAYS go out of my way to get a tasty Portillo's sandwich anytime one is near me). 

Tony's version of the Italian tomato beef sandwich is sooooooooooo good. The crispy-outer, soft-centered bread is perfect and the well portioned flavorful beef is soaked in mildly tangy tomato juice. The peppers offer the perfect zip.

For those that have some serious FOMO (fear of missing out), be sure to get there before 1PM as they often sell out of this delicious sando. 

I go there anytime I want a delicious treat...thank goodness this place is only a couple blocks from my office. 

Enjoy!!!
author: Roman R.

description:
The good: Tony's Slice House is open on Monday and Tuesdays, when Big Tony is out surfing or whatever.

The bad: on those days, the only thing you can get are New York-style slices and calzones. Cheese only is $3.75, with toppings $5 for a big slice. I had the meat lover. Quality was definitely above average, but not worth a special trip. But at least you can say you had pizza from Tony's.

Seating is a single wide banquette  inside, and several outdoor tables. If the weather is lousy, plan on taking it with you.
author: Otis M.

description: I had a vegetarian slice which was excellent...one of the best if not the best New York style slices I've had in San Francisco. However, I can't get over the fact that the slice was $5.50. With tax and everything I paid $6.98 for a single slice of pizza! And it wasn't extremely large, made to order, or anything like that. While the quality is there, I feel like they are charging this price "because they can". The cashier lady also was not the friendliest and seemed a bit irritated when I asked questions. I regrettably have to give this a 3. Food is definitely a 5 but service and price bring it down.
author: Michael S.

description: I don't ever complain much, but the 3 minute experience we had was poor. We ordered 2 slices and I signed a receipt. I never grabbed my copy. They were yelling for numbers like they were bothered. They called our number, my wife said sorry we didn't get a receipt. The guy sighed and just looked at us. My wife told him what we got, he tapped the box and walked away. We saw other insistent of the workers just being bothered. The zza was good, but their actions killed the experience
author: Anthony D.

description:
Is pizza meant to be eaten indoors with a fork and knife, seated in a plush booth? Or outside on uneven metal chairs in huge unlady-like mouthfuls? It could up for debate, but when you're hungry, there is only one option. 

The display case wasn't very stocked when we went (but the line was still going strong). Hoping that perhaps the fates would be kind and they would still have some of the special menu items listed on the large board up top, I asked the cashier whether they were making more pizzas. Unfortunately, what you see is all you can get. ); Lesson learned: come early to try more flavors! I'll be back for that Purple Potato. And maybe add another star.

I was tempted to try a dipped sandwich or calzone, but in the end it was back to basics. Tony makes LOTS of pizza, and in varying types. For reference, the Sicilian pan pizzas are the thick, rectangular slices. I tried two different slices: the Picante and NY Meat Lover. Both are DELICIOUS and filling, requiring a delicate balance of both hands under a double-layer of oil-soaked paper plates while and a constant supply of napkins. If you must, I suppose you could get some plastic knives and forks inside... The NY Meat Lover was tastier in my opinion, a generous I-dream-of-meat mixture of flavors. The Picante was good, but only if you enjoy peppers. Some of them were quite sour. 

We sat outside on the line of metal chairs and tables set out specifically for the casual pizza diners of Tony's. If you're REALLY lucky, you might be able to catch the group at the semicircular booth inside leaving, but don't bet on it. On a chilly SF evening, we had to jiggle our legs and fidget in order to stay warm outside, even with the pizza. Luckily, we were able to warm up inside Naia up the street AND get dessert.
author: Helen S.

description:
Tony, you broke my heart! I've been going to Tony's since they've opened (North Beach resident), I love the pie and Cappo's is my fave deep dish so I'm a Tony fan. But the slice house service is TERRIBLE.
You have a bunch of kids running the house with no quality control. Just finished a New Yorker pie and it was soggy, more naan bread than pizza pie. 

I see the quality and passion you have and that is what I want from the slice house, please make some changes.
author: Alex M.

description: This place was hoppin' on a Saturday night at 9pm and it was not slowing down. My company and I just got slices: pepperoni, plain cheese and veggie. They were tasty, maybe slightly on the too oily side - I had to soak up the oil on my slice with a napkin. And maybe there was more corn meal on the crust than ideal, but it was still enjoyable slices.
author: Pam H.

description: The food was good but the service sucked!  The girl taking our order was soooooo rude and had a serious RBF!!!  The sprite fountain drink wasn't working properly so it was basically soda water and I asked if I would have something else and she just stared at me.  I finally asked if I could have a coke and she slammed it down in front of me.
author: Holly M.

description: Excellent, excellent pizza! Try the original pizza and the vegetarian pizza...dripping well-cooked cheese in every bite. The long queues explain the popularity with locals and tourists alike. They don't have a big place to eat inside, so if it's chilly and cold outside, you are better off with a take-away!
author: Rupin K.

description:
Tony's Pizza Slice House is the ABSOLUTE BEST!!!!!

SPECIAL THANKS to Damon, Rudy, Ron, Angel, Oscar, Iovanny, Humberto & Matt for being such cool guys and so sweet to me!!!!!

I doubt most patrons realize how many pizza world championship awards Tony Gemignani has, but he has many!  So it's no wonder that people like me keep coming back often year after year.  

Everything is so delicious right down to the crust. The dough is hand-mixed and made with San Felice flour and proofed in Napoletana boxes, and the toppings are of such fine quality.

I recently went to a few other slice houses (only because they were in close proximity to wear I was), and the contrast between that mediocre pizza & Tony's was striking!  Tony's is so vastly superior that I don't think I could choke down slices from anywhere else again!
author: Paula M.

description: Tony's is absolutely amazing. There's this moment(or rather several moments) after biting into the pizza where you sit in silence and bask in the glory of the pizza. Go on Tuesdays or Saturdays when they have the margherita. It tastes like love! And the employees are super friendly! When people ask what there is to do in SF, my answer is always Tony's - you must try it.
author: Grace H.

description: I came here with my husband when we went to San Francisco and we were starving. Luckly we found this pizza place and let me tell you.  It's delicious. The slice is so big it's guaranteed to fill you up. I don't remember how much we paid but I don't think it was expensive at all. We wanted to go back the next day but we didn't have time. I'd highly recommend this place if you're craving pizza!
author: Brenda C.

description: Super nasty expensive overpriced for no reason what so ever barely any sauce on the pizza people don't really have any taste buds I don't understand how this place got 4 stars I'd rather go to golden boy anytime
author: Jhon G.

description:
Crust like paper...In a good way!

Ordered: 3 slices of pepperoni to go

Pros: quick to-go beside the restaurant, fresh, generous portion, thin crust, crispy, deliciousness

Cons: outside seating is limited, parking is an issue, very busy (which can be seen as a good thing)

Overall: good first experience and recommendable

Final Hashtag: #WillGoAgainAndBringAFriend
author: Cel A.

description:
I went with my coworker Oban and it was delicious. He's Canadian by the way. We both got the meat lover, but he finished his crust and I couldn't. I would recommend this place for all special events such as: weddings, bar mitzvah, birthdays, funerals, whatever the special occassion may be. I've lived in SF for ages, but totally hesitated to come because of the wait. 

However, I only discovered today that there's a slice house. Score!! So yum. Would love to come here everyday!!
author: Alex C.

description:
This was over hyped... I paid Tony's a visit due to all the raves I've heard, but it wasn't over the top amazing like how I was told. Since this is a slice house, maybe the slice I ordered wasn't the freshest "hot out of the oven" pizza, but even so, it wasn't all so great.

I'm pretty sure this place makes amazing pizza, but this review is based solely on the Meat lover's pizza. If I visit SF again, maybe I'll give this place another try. However, Vegas is closer for me, and they have Secret Pizza, which I believe is amazing.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Always delicious! Seriously no one does pizza like Tonys! The coal fired pizza is phenomenal! Hell their cheese from the slice house is even bursting with flavor! Bravo!
author: Christopher R.

description: Delicious pizza!!! Came over here because the wait next door was 1 hr 45 minutes. Ordering was a bit confusing and unorganized, but the place was slammed!  Ordered 2 slices-NY Cheese and Pepperoni. Crust was crispy and had that nice coal fired taste to it. Served very HOT and was enjoyable sitting out on the patio. It's a must do. I would do their restaurant next door if the wait isn't too long.
author: Marcie C.

description:
Uh, no.

I use to frequent in early 2015 when the pizza was cheaper and tasted better. But as of my last visit, I waited in a long line for dry, burned pizza.  

Usually the ingredients are tasty but I had the potato pizza and cheese pizza slices which were overcooked / dry and too salty.  And I paid a lot more than I did in early 2015, a 68% increase in less than a year?  

No thanks.
author: Jen L.

description:
Tasty pizza made on delicious dough (a little salty a little sweet) with a tangy sauce that doesn't need to drown the slice. Get the pepperoni!

The staff is pretty friendly too. Be kind, and they'll take of you.  There's a line out the door for a reason!

(As a tourist in town, I stopped in for a second night in a row because it was open late and served a damn good slice my first night. Was happy to be recognized and given large slices!)
author: GB M.

description: I have TRIED to like this slice.  Twice it has been inedible.  First time it was burnt to a crisp, whereupon the manager begrudgingly took 10 minutes to open the register to refund my money.  Generally there is too much cornmeal on the underside of the crust.  There is no consistency to the slices.  One day OK.   The next time not.  The plain slice is $5.50 with tax and can not (now or ever) compare well with Arinell's.  Last time I had this experience I went next door to the pizza sit down restaurant and asked the hostess why Tony doesn't visit this slice house more often in order to fix what's wrong.  She mouthed a bland reply to the effect that the pizza business is complex...blah blah blah.  Never again.
author: susan k.

description: I recommend Tony's slice house. If you're looking for that quick and inexpensive NY style pizzas and Italian beef sandwich, this place GOT it. The place is small, but the atmosphere and the cashiers/cooks attitude and along with the old school hip hop playing, transform you back to that concrete jungle vibe.
author: RC C.

description:
Stay away tourists: please read this!!!! Don't trust all the press. Most unprofessional experience I have had in a long time and I have worked in the field.

Ugh after 30 Minutes of being on hold and hung up on-  with indifference by their staff- I was using the number on their Yelp and on their website.. I was told they don't Actually take delivery orders. I have to use a third party service...read below

Real time: Waiting for Alex the manager to pick up after the horrible service I just experience. Supposedly she is in the office.  If that is even the managers real name...10 minutes- no response accept for she is right here...put on hold again. Took her 15 minutes to pick up-- she was nice but they still couldn't get me a pizza or a discount for ruining my mealtime experience. 

- I just called to place a delivery. Female answered. Asked if I could be put on hold. Just waited 15 min to place an order for pizza only to be hung up on...no one ever came back except to hang up on me. 

Called back out of principle: guy picked up don't say anything- just placed on hold again

Called back a third time: Guy answers says can I put you on hold. I say "I was just on hold for 15 min and your company hung up on me"- his response was a I don't care flippant "I don't know who did that but we are a little busy..." But no apology or how can I help you..

Avoid this place - they are a little too busy and their staff wastes your time.
author: Olga G.

description: Lines can be long and seating hard to come by but the slices are always delicious. Tried the four cheese, pepperoni, margherita & Sicilian combo. All were delicious, but the margherita was especially so. Great spot for a little something or casual meal.
author: Jess C.

description: Best pizza ever! I definitely recommend coming here and getting the pepperoni slice. If you don't want to sit inside, they have a to go window which is just as great!
author: Jocelyne C.

description: Best Pizza I've ever had, everytime I come to San Francisco I won't leave without grabbing a slice of all meat Pizza. Crave the flavor!  Repeat customer!!
author: Kelly L.

description:
I hate lines. Why? Because my time is worth so much more than anyone else's, damnit. I love pizza. Why? Because carbs and meat and cheese, damnit. This makes my relationship with Tony Gemangi's...difficult, as they're notable for their incredible pizza and obnoxious lines.  The answer? Tony's Coal Fired Pizza.

You get the same giant slices: beautifully charred crust, thick tomato sauce, expertly melted cheese, and killin' meats as the original (that sausage...My God.) without the line, blathering tourists or temptation to order a non-pizza item. If you come at the right time, you might even be able to snag a slice of their grandma's or Detroit style. The best part? These puppies come out fast. Beautiful. Take them to Washington square park and soak in the ambiance, rays, and grease.

Downsides? The selection can be limited, Chicago beef sandwiches are only served after 3:00 (which means that I'll probably be drunk if I ever get one), and the prices are justifiably high for a slice of the best in the city, making Tony's a rare indulgence.

4.5 stars...mmm...

Near the 30/45 8 and 39.

DO get a beer from the corner store and dine al fresco in the park.

DO NOT expect me to share.
author: Casey U.

description:
Next door to the main Tony's Pizzaeria, this slice house is meant for take out orders, whether it be slices, ordering a whole pizza. It's also a great place to avoid waiting over an hour for a seat at the main restaurant.

I ordered the gigante, which was basically a combo pizza-- with everything you can possibly want on a pizza.  The pizza was sicilian style with a thick crust, which my family loved. You would think that because of the thickness of all the toppings stacked ontop would leave the pizza uncooked. However, the pizza was cooked perfectly and not overcooked/dry as well. 

I also love how they have a variety of temperature/ style the pizza are baked in. The guy who took my order was also incredibly nice. I was told that it would take about 20-25 mins for the pizza to be ready but I got my order in about 15mins.
author: Jenny N.

description: tony pizza wow some good stuff the coal oven bring out the flavor and smokeyness of the pizza and the meats cheese u can tell they put hard work and time into making there pizza for 6 dollar a slice u get a big slice of pizza a good and quick lunch spot to check out in san francisco will stop by for sure to  get some more pizza check it out yelp on yelpers
author: sushiatown s.

description: Stopped here for a slice on the late night after some HH action.  The slice was big and delicious and served up fast.  There were a few outside seats that worked out as a perfect spot to chow down.
author: Ty C.

description: Just yummy! Seating is a low-grade war, but the park is right next door. Counter is efficiently nice. Helped me understand the difference between a Stromboli and calzone... Inventive styles of pie!
author: Jesse A.

description: I go to tony's all the time and I love it but recently the service at the slice house hasn't been great. After the person before me ordered I stepped up and the woman who was working the cash register walked away, pulled out her phone and was talking to two co-workers closer to the oven. The man working to the left, where they heat up the slices, looked back and noticed I was there and helped me. I think the workers are a little too comfortable, or lazy, here. The restaurant is great however. 5 stars for the restaurant!
author: Sabrina M.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!

I stumbled across this place 2 years ago on my bachelor party... like in the most literal meaning of stumbled ever..... anyway, couldn't find it again... nobody in the group could remember where the heck we were, but, we knew the pizza was AMAZING!!! So I have spent the last two years jobless, homeless, wondering aimless into the night looking for this place to have their amazing pizza again!!!

Ok, I have a job, and a house, and had my aim with me... but I never stopped looking!! (When I was in the city... so 4 times)  

BUT, the pizza is seriously amazing!  We sat next to a couple of people from NY and they thought it was some of the best pizza ever.  I am not sure why NY people get automatic street cred on their opinions of pizza but,  truth be told, they liked this pizza so they know what is good!!

Let this be proof!! NY people who like Tony' pizza are smart and know what they are talkin about!!!

Great pizza!! Trust me!!!
author: Mike H.

description: Hands down the BEST meatballs I've ever had in my entire life (aside from my husbands, ofcourse!) They were moist and well seasoned. Just perfection! We also had the pizza, which again, was just divine. Loved the food and everything about this restaurant.
author: Christy P.

description: If you really can't stand waiting in line for 2 hours to get a table at Tony's, The Slice House is probably your next best alternative to try Tony's award-winning pies.   This was actually where I got my first taste of Tony's pizza (http://bit.ly/1gRMQdr).  They pretty much have most of the same menu from the restaurant and they also serve slices if you're really on the go and don't have much time to wait.  Seating here is very limited though with a few tables inside and outside.  It's definitely worth it to stop by to try Tony's award-winning pies.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Drove down to San Francisco for a weekend getaway.  Our first stop was this pizza place I saw on DDD.  We got our pizza to go instead of waiting to be seated on the restaurant side. The meat lovers pizza was amazing! !!! Hands down best pizza I've ever had. 
Kind of pricey for a slice but worth it. Make sure you're adding a slice of pizza and not the whole pie :) we made that mistake
author: Sasha V.

description: One of the best slices of pizza I've ever had !! The pepperoni was amazing the crust was perfect ! This will be one of the places we have to stop by every time we come to the Bay Area . I probably could eat a whole pizza - look forward to trying different kinds of pizza
author: Jennifer S.

description:
My bf and I came to grab pizza for dinner at the World Famous Tonys. The actual restaurant had a 2.5hr wait, so we opted to get a few slices next door. 

1st impression: HORRIBLE SERVICE
As soon as we walked in, it was total chaos! The people working there were extremely rude.. not sure if that's part of the "tough New Yorker act" but everyone was extremely rude. 
(If you cant handle the stress of food service, then don't get a job in it!)
They impatiently waited for us to order our food. We asked for one of their famous All Meat pizzas with the other half Clam and Garlic. The cashier just said "NO"...?! Uhhh No what? After rolling her eyes at me she then she said we couldn't do half n half.. 
We then asked for 1 pizza just the clam and garlic and she then said they weren't making Oven Pizza anymore! Really? It's 5:45pm... prime dinner traffic in SF?!  
My bf and I had to resort to just a slice of soggy looking pepperoni pizza.. We asked for napkins only to have another worker lash out at us. Before leaving the register, the Cashier lady yelled at my bf bc he forgot he his receipt! 

Does the pizza taste good? Yes.. its good.. but its also very very oily. They also screwed up our order and gave us the wrong pizza. Again.. another star off. We ended up getting combo slices instead of pepperoni, which to me, sucks, bc of all toppings, combo is my least favorite. 

Will I come back? No fucking way. For what? To get treated like shit by the wanna-be "New Yorkers" with the atrocious attitude? No thanks..
I'm extremely disappointed.
author: Guerrero M.

description:
Quick for those of us on the go in the area! The actually pizzeria is just right next door, so if you do have the time to order a whole pie, definitely go there to sit down!

The slice house is a tiny shop that sells Tony's pizza by the slices :) Don't worry, it's the same awesome quality as from the original store next door! Staff are very friend, joking, and quick with orders. There are a few small tables inside, but plenty of outdoor seating outside! 

Slices are very generous and always tasty. If you haven't had Tony's, definitely try the margarita pizza! Sauce is impeccable and the crust is very tasty as well. :)
author: Rachel C.

description:
Mamma Mia, delizioso cibo!! Tony's truly delivered a blazing hot pizza right out of the oven. We were supposed to get a table and take seat next door in their restaurant - but we soon realized that they also have a slice house.

It worked out perfectly, and 5 minutes later, we were sitting at a table and chomping away on their Meat Lover's Pizza and the Pepperoni Pizza.
It was as close as it gets to the real deal New York pizza, and it was delicious. The melted cheese and tomato sauce was pretty spot-on.

The only downside was all the grease and dripping fat that sogged the crust and made it soft and doughy. 

The slice is big enough to fill one person up with carbs to sprint down Stockton, to Fisherman's Wharf for a bowl of Clam Chowder. Saga continues...
author: Sina N.

description: Pretty yummy cheese pizza. The dough/crust was chewy and crunchy... Just perfect. However, I think $6 (including tip) for a slice of super thin NY style pizza is a little pricey.
author: Betty T.

description:
While I love the original Tony's pizza in North Beach, the operations at the Slicehouse are horrendous. Numerous times we have ordered via telephone and when we arrived to pick up our pizza, the order has been "lost". 

Most recently we ordered via telephone and were told to pick up our pizza in 25 minutes. When we arrived, we were told to join the line out the door to wait to pay while our pizza sat on the shelf getting cold. Why do you take phone orders but do not have a pick up/pay cash register line dedicated to phone orders? If you are too overwhelmed with orders, then you should not accept phone orders. 

If we are to ever return to the slicehouse, a dedicated line/cashier for phone orders needs to be established. I will not wait in line for another 30 minutes to pay for now-cold pizza which I ordered 55 minutes ago. I find it despicable that Tony G approves of selling cold pizza with his name on it.
author: Meghan M.

description: We drove from Idaho straight here. The food was wonderful! Best pizza I had all day and the meatballs . . . I'd gladly drive another 500 miles for the creamy mushroom and pancetta sauce-topped meatballs. My only regret is that I had to share them with my family.
author: Cheryl C.

description: The pizza was good but I had better. I feel like the cashier didn't tell me the best way to order. He was gonna let me buy glass bottled Soda when it was cheaper to get just a regular fountain drink when that has free refills. And I ordered a few slices of pizza but to find out, I could have just ordered a whole pizza for the same price. Wish the cashier had more knowledge to help the customer out
author: Gloria R.

description:
The sister operation next door is a sit-down restaurant with a big reputation and a mile-long wait on weekends. No waiting on Tuesdays though, because they're not open. If you want a New York style slice on that particular day of the week, you have to go to the slice house. 

DLW and I were tourists who didn't get around to the pizza thing until afternoon on that day. We ordered a couple of slices, and waited about five minutes. The pizzas on display were not the ones they used to fill orders, a la Sbarro. They freshly prepared our order, and the quality showed. It's a proper NY slice, perfect for folding, slightly charred underside, right combination of crisp and chewy, not overloaded with toppings. It's not cheap at $4 a slice, but I'd take one of these over a whole Sbarro any day of the week.
author: Mark A.

description: This pizza was absolutely AMAZING!  It was recommended to us by our Uber driver. I will definitely be back!  The pizza was so go that my teenage son carried the 1 remaining piece with him on the plane. He said it was good cold too.
author: L M.

description: I just wanted to start by saying we love Tony's Pizza.   My husband and I were craving for Tony's but we didn't want to wait for a table so we decided to order pizza from Slice House this past Sunday.  I ordered the pizza at 6:10 and they told me the pizza would be ready in 25 min.  My husband gets to Slice House by 7:10 and there are 2 guys working the register.  The guy with a cell phone charges my husband for the pizzas and tells him to wait. He noticed there were a lot of pizzas flying out of the kitchen.  He waits for another 15 min and noticed a lot of people ordering slices of pizza and whole pizzas.  After waiting a total of 40 min all those people who ordered after us were getting their food.  So my husband asked the guy with a cell phone about the order,  he seems distracted with something else so he points my husband to the other guy working the counter.  The other guy sees the receipt and immediately gives my husband the pizzas that's been sitting in the warmer this whole time.  I don't know what happened but it seems like the pizza had been ready since 7pm and we didn't hear our number called either.  We like the pizza but service sucks here.  Nobody acknowledged my husband waiting by the door for 40 min and we didn't even get an apology for mix up.  I don't think we will be back.  Next time we're going next door to Tony's Pizza.
author: Aimee L.

description:
Avoid the line at Tony's. 

I repeat, AVOID THE LINE AT TONY'S.

Why wait for 2+ hours on a freaking Wednesday night when you can grab amazing slices of pizza to go and sit in the glorious sun to make sweet love to Margherita?! They serve the same food so really, unless you cannot be satiated if you are not waited upon.. Go here and get the same amazing pizza to-go.

Their Margherita pizza is amazing. I can't decide if I like Tony's or Delfina's better. Perfectly seasoned tomato sauce base, insanely delicious crust, fresh basil chiffonade, and rich mozzarella... Perfecto!! I wish they would put more mozzarella on the pizza though. You only get 1-1.5 chunks per slice. 

After you finish, go to caffe Greco to grab an espresso and tiramisu. There's your perfect summer night in north beach!
author: Michelle K.

description: Oh man this pizza spot was bomb. Would definitely come back again. They sell by the slice and the line is out the door but totally worth the wait.. will b back again.
author: Jesus A.

description: Best pizza I've had in California hands down!  This is the take out by the slice restaurant. The main Tony's restaurant is next door with a bar area but they only sell the whole pizza pie.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Meat.  Ball.  Sub.

I bet I've had at least 40 meatball subs at Tony's side door.  My wife is disgusted by my ability to eat the same thing over and over again.  She feels variety is the spice of life... which kind of contradicts her feelings regarding monogamous marriage, but I digress.

Their meatball subs are great, pizza is good (great for San Francisco), and the ability to get Tony's Pizza without waiting for a table at their adjacent restaurant is priceless.

In short.  Monogamy is great.  I'll likely eat here again tonight.
author: Kyle L.

description:
Whenever I go out in north beach, we usually end up here for a slice. 
Their slices are pretty big, and it always hits the spot.
author: Lacy S.

description: I'm from NY/NJ area.  I like legit pie.  It's hard to find legit pie since I moved out here 6 years ago, but after 6...long...freaking...years..... Tony's!!!  How have I never had this place before???!!!!!  As good as it gets.  Even better than what I can find now half the time when I get back East to visit home!  Price was right too.  Around $5 or so for a huge slice, equivalent to what you'd get on the boardwalk back east, so you are getting enough.  Can't wait to come back!
author: LyraM45 H.

description:
Called in to order a pizza, was put on hold for way too long to tell me orders are only thru a 3rd party app that I've never heard of. Told me I can find it on their actual website but it doesn't exist. 

Waste of time, not worth this trouble.
author: Esther H.

description: If I lived in North Beach, I would have Tony's every day as if it were NY. The dough is very reminiscent of the East. Tony's Slice House will pretty make make every slice they have in their main restaurant, and they now do the magherita too, which is awesome. Slices are heated really quickly, and service keeps the line moving quickly. Your amazing slice will be ready to go in about 5 minutes, so you can go explore more of the area quickly or sit outside on a sunny day (every day unless it's raining) to people watch while enjoying a hot slice of the best slice in North Beach and almost all of the Bay Area. Man, I miss NY. Get the veggie or cheese (the regular). You'll thank me later.
author: Danny C.

description:
It's not cheap but their pizza is the most delicious I have had on the west coast.  (Lived in New Jersey for 7 years).  Their Sicilian pizza is what is worth the hassle of getting there/parking.  Their regular slices were good too. 

Just wish parking wasn't such a total pain in the ass.
author: Madhuri K.

description: Excellent Chicago Italian beef and pizza! This is my favorite pizza place in the city.
author: Klarenz D.

description: Tony's Napoletana is great! But if you're in a rush or just want to enjoy some great SF weather, grab a slice or two from the Slice House and savor them while you people watch at Washington Square Park.
author: Rose A.

description:
Heard great things about this place, but unfortunately, we never got to try it because the service was absolutely TERRIBLE. 

The girl taking orders was extremely RUDE. There are better ways to direct your customers without adding snide remarks and rolling your eyes. When our friend was trying to explain a misunderstanding, she dismissed comments by being condescending.

When we asked to speak to the manager, she claimed to be just that. FALSE. There's NO WAY in the world you can have that attitude and still have a running business. I hope REAL management will do something with her and pizza boy (tall, blonde) because it would be a shame to lose out on more customers because of their unprofessionalism. 

AVOID this place if you don't want to be treated like low-class citizen.
author: Cecilia N.

description: $5-$6/slice for dry pizza that skimps on ingredients. Crust is doughy and there's no sauce. Flavors weren't impressive.
author: Julie L.

description: Amazing. Been searching the Bay Area for over ten years for an authentic slice of good pizza (as a Bostonian and previous resident of NYC, I have high standards) and the search is over. This is it! It's always busy and has limited seating both indoor and out, but with a big park across the street, who cares?! Such good pizza!
author: Lex B.

description: This is a quick take out by the slice place, pizza was really good! The napoletana is 2 doors down and is more of a sit down restaurant, this place you can either get a slice to go or sit at the tables outside. I chose to grab a slice and walk through little Italy w/ my mom. Line can get pretty long at times but it tends to move fast since ppl are just buying slices to go. It's worth it, pizza is thin NY style and I really enjoyed it.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Best pizza in North Beach! I say so for two main reasons: 1. They have the Slice House which serves a great purpose for those late nights when you need a slice before heading home and also a good quick slice at any time of the day. 2. The actual restaurant is to-die-for. The pizza is amazing still but the quality you get when you splurge and get the meatballs as an appetizer or as an extra topping. Not many places around where I feel comfortable taking a random group of friends after the bar and still be wanting to come back the next night to take your mother! 

Why 4 stars? The Slice House is a get what they have available type of eatery. If they only have cheese available, you're eating cheese. It's great for lunch though as their calzones are delicious but never in stock late night.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Pizza is good but it's not the greatest. 

And what is the reasoning behind putting something on the menu and half the time it's sold out? It's poor planning and execution on the food service manager and owner when you are out of a Italian roast beef sandwiches and it's only an hour and a half after opening. This is the second time this happened- and after an hour drive to get to this place and another half hour to find parking, it shows the lack of consideration for your customers. fYI- if it wasn't for your customers, your restaurant would not exist.  So you're welcome. 

Won't be coming back here for another disappointing experience.
author: Aleli L.

description:
7x7 100 Things To Eat in SF Before You Die 2013

#84  New York-style cheese slice at Tony's Slice House

2+ hour wait next door at Tony's Restaurant or 30 minutes from the time you order to the time you get your food....Yeah I'll take slice house! 

The dough has a firm bite to it throughout. In fact, it proved to be quite a challenge to cut but eventually it was accomplished. 

With so many countless rave reviews, I am going to be honest, I simply did not feel the same way. I thought the pizza was fine but nothing so outstanding that justified a 2+hr wait and the numerous 5 star ratings. With anything, its all subjective and based on personal preferences so while I didn't agree with the masses, I don't feel its that off based.

Overall Thoughts

I would be willing to try the restaurant and see if I have a different reaction but for now I am feeling just A-ok with Tony's
author: Eddie W.

description: This place should be ASHAMED to advertise that their pizza is made in a coal oven. If you're gonna use a coal oven (which is really bad for the environment), at least use it to MAKE GOOD PIZZA! A good pizza needs to have a crust that has a very thin layer of crispness on the bottom with the rest of it being soft. Having lived in NY, I know for a fact this is possible to do with a coal oven, and to some extent, without one. This place's crust has no such crispness. Furthermore, I had a NY meat lover slice and the sausages were to salty I had to pick them off before it was edible. Even the $1 slices in NY were miles ahead of what that was.
author: Guorui W.

description:
Hands down the best and most authentic Italian-style pizza in SF bay area that I've had so far!! 
The chef is a "Triple Crown winner for baking at the International Pizza Championships in Lecce, Italy".. enough said !
author: Wissam A.

description:
When you drive around North Beach swerving
around street construction, MUNI buses, taxis,
and tourists THEN snagging a rare parking spot,
I think a slice of pizza is in order.  Why not
reward yourself for such an incredible feat
(PLUS getting there early) :)

As you walk into Tony's Coal-Fired Pizza and 
Slice House, it is as advertised as cheese,
pepperoni, combos/specials and even
two sandwiches on display wait for your
attention.  I went with the Meat Lovers, a slice
covered in pepperoni, sausage slices and
bacon (drool).  Service was efficient as they
produced a heated slice on a wax paper and
paper plate.

Did the fold test and the tip of the pizza did droop
(oh well).  In any case, it was a nice tasty
combination of meats on a good crust that
made it worth the trip down to Union and
Stockton Streets.
author: W L.

description:
OMG! Holy Smokes! Madonna Mia! Ridiculous! Screeming! Out of Control!
Chicago Hot Italian Beef Sandwich...better than any hot beef I have ever had in Chicago. I've had about 18 Hot beefs in Chi-Town that were highly recommended by locals ...they were great until I had Tony's..then I knew. Its the spices, bread, beef quality, how it's cooked and huge the portion...enough for 2 normal people. The portion is right for me and I don't share on this one.
Get it soaked also with Giardinara...go mild or 50/50 mild/hot. If you go all hot..I guarantee you will burn more than 3 times...fricken too hot... This is the "to go"  counter next to Tony's Pizza on the corner if you are in a rush. I call in my order and double park, run in and grab-n-go.
Pizza? yeah ok, I'de rather sit in the restaurant and enjoy that work of art and have a personal relationship with it..
Let me know what you think.
author: Rudy T.

description: I would come here again and try the actual side down place. I liked the idea of going on a nice day...it was 75F today and getting a slice of $5 pizza and then sitting outside on the chairs was really nice. Had it be cold then I don't know if I would go back unless I needed food and had just gone to a bar. I think if you have the time then you should try the actual Tony's pizza. In general the people here were really nice and the pizza was good. It expected a different type of pizza but when we got to the front of the line we got the Sicilian and were really pleased with it. The bread was amazing (thick, buttery and worth finishing every bit) and the toppings were good. I found the price tag to be a bit high for take out pizza compared to NYC and that the pizza could have been sitting out for a REALLYY long time and just reheated. I would pay that much more often if I knew it was more fresh?
author: Lily P.

description: Some of the best pizza I've ever had! The pepperoni is delicious and the crust is amazing. Definitely try a slice of the 4 cheese. Can't wait to try a calzone!
author: Anthony J.

description: Even tho cold and too greazy the pizza is pretty good but the whole staff vibe - if you're too cool for school kid, drop out
author: Elias W.

description: Awesome spot for pizza in SF! I am a native and this was my first time here! We had the famous margarita pizza! It was so hard to choose between that one and the clam pizza. There were only 2 of us and we knew we wouldn't be able to do 2 pizzas! We also ordered the garlic bread with cheese, chorizo mussels, meatballs, and the tiramisu! Don't skip that dessert because it is truly delicious. Everything we ordered tasted awesome. Will def be back to try the clam pizza
author: Alice Z.

description: No pizza review for Slice House, though the slices are freaking awesome, the sauce turns me into a school girl with her brand-new Tiger Beat magazine.  No this review is for the Italian Beef sandwich.  It's $12.50 for the Cheef (Hot Italian Beef with spicy giardiniera and cheese).  It's not overly big but I couldn't eat it all in one sitting and I'm no small man.  And they dip it or "wet" it depending on how much sauce you want.  I was born in Chicago.  I've eaten my weight in Italian Beef sandwiches.  I took a bite and this sandwich took me back to being a little boy.  It's honestly one of the best sandwiches I've had in The City.  Triple high-five in slo-mo.  You nailed it.  I live in the neighborhood now, this WILL be a staple on the non-diet lunch plan. They are going to have to crane me out of my apartment in a year.  (PS get extra napkins).
author: Mark C.

description:
It's late at night and after a chat over a cup of coffee, my friends and I were craving some pizza. There's a few tables inside but there's more seating outside. Luckily it wasn't too cold of a night and we were able to grab a table next to the building.

Our order:
Cal Italia: ($19.50) Asiago, Mozzarella, Italian Gorgonzola, Croatian Sweet Fig Preserve, Prosciutto Di Parma, Parmigiano, Balsamic Reduction, no sauce
Prosciutto E Pomodorini: ($18.50) Mozzarella, Prosciutto Di Parma, Arugula, Cherry Tomatoes, Parmigiano, Vine-ripened Tomato Sauce

Cal Italia which is one of their Classic Italian pizza baked in their domed gas brick oven with hand tossed rustic medium crust. It was a gold medal winner of the Food network's Pizza Champions Challenge as well. Unfortunately we didn't get much fig in our pizza, mostly tasted the balsamic reduction. The Prosciutto E Pomodorini had very fresh veggies and the sauce was fantastic. Absolutely loved the brick-oven taste on the crusts. 

They do have the option for gluten-free crust as well for an additional fee ($3).
author: Kitty K.

description: Called in an order, they said it would be ready in 15 min. Drove all the way there just to be told they lost our order and don't have any of what I ordered left had to drive in circles for 15 min while they make different food, which was marginal at best
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Best pizza I've had in SF... 

However the customer service was Horrible!!! My buddy asked how long till our Pie was ready, 15 or 20 min after ordering, and both the cashier and pizza makers made both him and I feel like shit just for asking... Of course they didn't know he had a flight to London an hour from then, but that's beside the point...

Then when the Pizza maker was done cutting the pie, he dropped it on the glass counter and said very sarcastically "Your pizza is ready...30 minutes, just like we said!"

For such a famous place to grab a slice, it's sad that the service will be the lasting memory I have...
author: Luis M.

description:
Ask me whats my favorite type of food and I will tell you pizza and sandwiches. I have traveled all over the USA and other countries eating those two items. With that in mind, pizza has two subcategories: 1.Pizza 2.Pizza Pie

Chicago style pizza is not pizza but pizza pie and it is amazing 
New York/Connecticut style pizza is pizza
AND BOTH ARE AMAZING depending on what you want at the time

We have that established so now Tony's Pizza review:

Pros:
1. Best west coast pizza and pizza pie I have ever had (sorry best North America Pizza and Pizza Pie are in Chicago, New York, and New Haven, Ct). However, this is the best pizza on the entire West Coast. 
2. We ordered 3 pizzas and all three were different and amazing. My friends loved the Margherita, I loved the New Yorker (obviously NY style) and the Grandma (more Chicago style).
3. Fun environment

Cons:
1. It is def' pricey, but it is well worht the price
2. The NY style pizza crust was good but not amazing. I like a tiny bit of crunch on my NY/Ct style pizzas
3. One of the best things in SF so that means a long wait and line. They dont take reservations, so be prepared to wait if you go around peak times.
4. We ordered calamari and it was okay (did not like their custom spicy calamari). Since their pizzas are beyond this world I would not recommend the calamari even though it is not bad, but their pizza is better. 

They have a extremely diverse menu which can be a good and bad thing. It makes it hard to decide which to decide but they are all amazing. So that means you have to try them all eh? Go here with the family, with a group of friends, date, or by yourself.  

Note: they have limits on how many pizzas they can make for certain types so you may want to go early.
author: Soroosh A.

description: hell yes! huuuge slices of DELICIOUS pizza, LADEN with quality ingredients!  the price is definitely fair, especially compared to what you get at other pizzerias in San Francisco. highly recommended this soul-satisfying eatery.
author: Grizzle J.

description: My family from LA was visiting for the holidays and we thought that we'd be sneaky and try and go to their mainstay restaurant a few days after Christmas, thinking we'd be beating the crowds.  Not so much.  The wait for a group of 7 was 2.5 hours.  So, we had to move on to another place.  A few days later, we were looking for a quick meal and found the Slice House.  We called in RIGHT when the opened and phoned in our order. 30 minutes later, I walked in, picked up our piping hot (and delicious smelling) New Yorker without any wait.  It doesn't stand up to their absolutely amazing Margherita, but this was certainly a wonderful secondary option.  So, if you're in a bind, have access to a phone and want delicious pizza to pick up, call Tony's!
author: Lisa I.

description: The best slice of pepperoni pizza to ever fill my face hole. WOW, it was so good. The dough, the cheese, the meat, the everything.
author: Lindsey K.

description:
Someone is being a hater and trying to flag and report my honest, real reviews and I don't like that. Anyways here's what was taken down: 

GOOD pizza (when it's fresh only), HORRIBLE service. Seriously I don't know how these current workers get to keep their jobs. Oh yeah, because this is a typical tourist trap place. 

It's not so much the fact that the service is ridiculously slow, it's that they are just very unorganized, very nonchalant, very lazy, and don't give a damn that there's chaos going on in the small shop. For some reason I was told when I went to pick up a delivery for somebody that there's only ONE line for all orders (phoned-in orders and people ordering slices to go). I saw the phoned-in order I was supposed to get, and I went up to touch it to see how long it had been sitting there. Surely enough it was already getting cold, and the female cashier even acknowledged that it was my to-go order, but she still VERY rudely tells me and another person that we have to get in line to pay. And the line is way out the door. And it LITERALLY takes MORE THAN 5 MINS EACH per transaction because she LEAVES the register after EVERY transaction (just leaves, she's not helping the pizza makers or doing any work, she just disappears). And of course again, she's the only cashier there. When they HAVE TWO REGISTERS THERE.

That just makes no type of sense at all; So you rather me get back in line to wait 45 min for a delivery order THAT I CAN ALREADY SEE SITTING IN THE FREAKING WINDOW, INSTEAD OF JUST GETTING THE TO-GO ORDERS OUT THE WAY???? SO NEW COMERS GET TO HAVE FRESH HOT PIZZA BUT THE DELIVERY CALLED IN ORDERS HAVE TO BE COLD???? WHAT TYPE OF SERVICE IS THAT??? THERE SHOULD BE ONE LINE FOR TO-GO/PHONED-IN ORDERS, AND ANOTHER LINE FOR REGULAR ORDERS. STOP BEING LAZY. You should WANT to get as many people out those long lines and out that small shop as possible! 

I DON'T KNOW WHO HIRED THESE SNOBBY YOUNGSTERS to work here but they BETTER be lucky it's a tourist trap place and not just some regular business where professionalism and organization has to be taken more seriously.They clearly have no customer service skills at all.  I seriously do not imagine the actual sit-down restaurant Tony's being like this. It's very sad actually. 

Glad their pizza isn't worth regular 45- min waits. Once is enough. Find something better.
author: Marquis A.

description:
Before heading over to The Saloon to see Ron Hacker and the Hacksaws play some down and dirty blues, I stopped at Tony's for a couple slices. I ordered a NY Meat Lovers and a Sicilian Combo, but they were out of the Sicilian. Instead, I had two slices of meat lovers which the gentleman taking my order said was a good choice. The slices came out quickly and were very good. The crust was nice and crisp. The sauce, cheese, and selection of different meats were very tasty. 

I would definitely recommend Tony's Slice House if you're in North Beach and looking for a quick bite.
author: Christian D.

description:
Tony's Pizza has won awards all over the country and so naturally I've been absolutely salivating to get over there. I mean winning a pizza contest in California cannot be hard. That's like Thor winning a strongest man competition against squishy human types. But winning in esteemed locations where pizza is actually consumed, like New York (sorry Chi-town, your soup in a biscuit dish isn't pizza), does peak my interest and get me excited. Which is why I was so disappointed in the end. I've been coming to the Bay Area for years and have learned that where pizza is concerned I must suspend my disbelief and just go with it, but Tony's is supposed to be different. It's supposed to be Napoletana style. It's supposed to be award winning. Sadly in the end it's just okay. 

When I arrived at the restaurant I was directed to the slice business on the side because I just wanted a pick-up pizza. The line was pretty quick and I only waited about 10 mins to order. I was suspicious when I read the menu and saw that they sell a variety of pizza like products, which is generally the hallmark of a pizza dabbler, not master. They had Chicago style (not pizza), Napoletana style (yes, pizza), NY (definitely pizza), and what I can only assume is California style labelled as by the slice (pizza?). The service staff was excellent, friendly, and helpful, so I pushed down my misgivings. I ordered a whole pie and was happy that they made them fresh. Definitely +1. They quoted me 20 mins, but has the pie out in 15. Another plus and I was on my way back to the hotel with some piping pizza in hand. I kept the lid closed while in the taxi to ensure that the pizza stayed as hot as possible. My hotel was only a quick 5-6 min drive away. Once I arrived I ran up the stairs juggling this giant pizza box all the way, and down the hallway into my room. Cracking open the box I smelled that delicious pizza aroma-- hot yeasty deliciousness with a hint of cheese and sauce. Oh joy!
I let my teeth sink into that pile of doughy delight awaiting the slight toothsome crunch of superior pizza... Nothing. Sigh. 

Don't get me wrong. The pizza is good. The crust had a nice dabbling of char and the rise on the end crust was classical perfection. The problem was the taste did not mirror the beauty of the pizza. The sauce was bland and for my taste there was a bit too much, which I had to painstakingly remove. The meat overwhelmed the cheese and I didn't get the sweet note you find in a high quality mozzarella. The ricotta was the real star and definitely elevated the pizza into the realm of 4 stars, but in the end I'm giving Tony's just 3 stars for being pretty okay in the land of pizza, but 5 stars in California-land.
author: Adina P.

description: What happened to the slices I ate last year?  They were thin & all had a toasty, coal-fired crust & taste?  Loved them & bought several over a period of weeks. Haven't been able to stop in for quite a while.  Those slices were 5 Star.  Thin toasty flavorful crust.  Great sauce & cheese.  Very Trenton-New York.  I've been in the Bay Area for 40 years but lived in New York & later Philly  from where we'd actually drive to Trenton for amazing pizza just like what I had at Tony's SF a year ago.  What Tony's Slice House pizza USED to be like.  The slice of pepperoni I bought tonight Had Nothing to Do with what I bought at Tony's a year ago.  Again, Will Someone at Tony's Tell Me What happened? Today's crust was soft & thicker.  Absolutely No Toasty Coal Fired Look or Flavor.  The edge was soft.  No crispyness at all.  Take a look at my pics of the bottom.  Off white & a little light brown with a tray screen pattern.  While large, the slice folded over like a soft, undercooked Dominoes slice.  I swear!  Loved the old Tony's crispy, coal oven flavored crunchy slice.  What I got tonight had nothing to do with what I ate a year ago!  Weird.  Tony, what's the story?
author: Joshua C.

description: Way overpriced for mediocre pizza. I am from NY so I am a little bias but $40 for a pizza, half cheese and pepperoni come on now. Better places to get pizza for much cheaper else where in the city.
author: Josiah M.

description: I went to Tony's next door previous to knowing about the Slice House and absolutely loved their pizza. When I found out that you can get Tony's pizza at the Slice House next-door without the hour wait, I was ecstatic. However, the slices of pizza I got at the Slice House were a complete 180 from the pizza I had next door. They were hard, crunchy, and barely edible. I got the margherita and pepperoni pizza. The mozzarella cheese and the tomato sauce were good, but the crust was almost like rock. The pepperoni slices were overly cooked, which made it crunchy. Again, the crust was the same as the margherita pizza and it was hard to eat. The cashier also lost my friend's order and ran out of the margherita even though she had ordered it. The cashier was annoyed that he had to go make another slice for her. With what the other reviewers have stated, I'm thinking this was an off night for them.
author: Hana K.

description: Great pizza! Only minus one star because it was really expensive ($5.50 for a slice of pep).
author: Audrey H.

description: I'm a pizza snob. I was born and raised in New Jersey and spoiled with great New York and New Jersey pizza. Brick/coal fired pizza is as New York as it gets and I review pizza every chance I get to in every city. The crust was nice and thick, fresh, and the toppings and portion of the pizza were on point. The pizza itself has a thin consistency that is not too thin to eat a slice with your hand (even though the slices are huge). The only negative thing I have to say is the problem I've had with every pizza place outside of the New York tri-state area. The pizza was ridiculously overpriced and you can buy $1-$2 slices in a hole in the wall pizzeria in New York with the same quality and quantity versus other cities which charge anywhere from $5-$8 dollars. I had a 16 inch half veggie and half cheese for $34 and the same pie averages at around $25 in many pizzerias in New York. Other than that, best tasting pizza I've ever tried in San Francisco.
author: Adel Y.

description: Excellent drop in for lunch and they have an amazing California veggie slice! Amazing
author: Omar S.

description: We stopped by here to get just a slice and man oh man are they some of the best slices and most hospitable people who will serve you here.  This is perhaps one of the best thin slice pieces of pizza in North Beach.  The SLICES are LARGE, 2 can probably fill most people.  The key here is skip the line that forms outside the main restaurant well before posted opening time (usually 12 NOON) and go next door to the counter that has to go slices.   Either way they are BOTH REALLY REALLY good.  We ate our slices, pepperoni, 4 cheese and plain cheese while watching the line form for the restaurant.  Tony KNOWS PIZZA and you will also if  you stop in at either place.  PIZZA that blows you AWAY GREAT!!!!!!!
author: Tim R.

description:
Most overrated pizza I've ever had in my entire life. I've had a better pizza from a CPK microwaveable pizza. Incredibly dry, no flavor, and burnt. Horrible.
4x cheese pizza: Worst white pizza I've ever had
author: Nick V.

description: Ok if you happen to be in the San Fran area and want a great tasting pizza ooo weee this is the place to go. First place is very clean small but it's the city so it's typically cramped but !its clean¡ I tried pepperoni and combo they were both great fresh ingredients you can taste ;-) I really enjoyed the food have a variety of food you can choose from just in case!! And all ingredients fresh and clean! Down side is lines can be out of line but hey when food tastes good.if you can make reservations please do so. If not just order to go and eat it where ever San Francisco scenery is gorgeous!!
author: Arlene M.

description: The service was generally quick. I enjoyed the sweet tasting sauce of the pizza and the crispiness of it. I would definitely would come back.
author: Andre N.

description: Cashier seemed very unhappy to be working on 4th of July. I understand we all want to have the day off and celebrate, but if you happen to be working - commit to your job and provide at least a not so unpleasant experience to the customer of the place you work for. Not even going to mention the lack of hygiene in this place. Cashiers who handled the money were also handling the pizza slices to the customers. The pizza guy was drying up his sweat and making pizzas at the same time ....I really am not a picky person and understand the level of service in a grab and go place specially in a national holiday, but this one was something to remember.... Disgusting :(
author: Samya D.

description: Went with the NY classic cheese slice. Friendly employees and quick service. Great ratio of cheese and sauce. Crust was crisp. Can't beat the price!
author: Christine R.

description:
The coal-fired pizza was the bomb!  Reminded us of Lombardi's Pizza in NYC, another coal-fired pizza restaurant.

The table service was very good.  One more star if the servers seemed a little more enthused to have a job.

We would definitely return there again.
author: G M.

description:
If you told me a couple of years ago, that I would be ordering a plain cheese pizza with no meat toppings, I would have slapped you, and then cried myself to sleep. 
I never liked plain cheese pizza until I discovered Tony's offering of New York Cheese pizza.  I have tried their pepperoni and meat lovers.  All excellent. Definitely recommended and beats Golden Boy pizza for the not so late (they close at 11 *insert sad face ) North Beach craving.
author: Hanna A.

description:
Stopped by late night for a slice of cheese, which was delicious.  It was a little on the pricey side - over $4, but certainly hit the spot.  Great crust, perfectly cooked, Tony knows how to do pizza.

There is a sit down restaurant and then next door is the slice house.  Both have outdoor seating.  The slice house has limited indoor seating.
author: Marilyn C.
